PostValue.explanation: This is a useful, practically-oriented report for the EA/practitioner community about how hands‑on MEL support can produce concrete program changes in animal advocacy organisations and about barriers to sustained adoption. If true, it meaningfully informs decisions by funders, capacity‑builders, and advocacy groups about investing in simplified, embedded MEL support — so it has moderate importance for operational EA work (not foundational theory). However the evidence is limited (small, self‑selected sample, likely social desirability and selection biases, no rigorous causal identification), so its load‑bearing power is moderate rather than high. For general humanity the post is narrowly focused and operational; it has low wider importance.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Overstated causal claims and weak counterfactuals. The post implies MEL drove the reported changes, but the data are largely self-reported, non-random, and lack a counterfactual (no comparison group, no baseline metrics, possible concurrent causes). Actionable fix: tone down causal language (e.g., say MEL was associated with or helped enable changes), and — if possible before publishing — add a short methods note or appendix that: a) lists other supports/changes happening concurrently for those orgs, b) reports any pre/post metrics or timelines for each change, and c) explains plans for future quasi-experimental or control comparisons (e.g., matched comparison groups, stepped rollout, or even plain pre-post measurement) to strengthen causal claims.

2) Ambiguous sample reporting and vague outcome definitions. Readers cannot judge the strength of the findings because denominators and definitions are inconsistent (you mention 27 orgs, 9 worked with extensively, 31 deliverables, 16 implemented changes, 13 in progress, 2 made without prompting — it is unclear how these numbers relate), and you do not define what counts as an “implemented change” or how sustainability was measured. Actionable fix: add a one-paragraph methods/data summary listing exact sample sizes, selection criteria, time windows, clear definitions for outcomes (what constitutes an implemented change vs in progress), and follow-up periods. Where space is tight, convert this to a short linked appendix or footnote rather than lengthening the main post.

3) Potential conflict of interest and limited validation. Because The Mission Motor both delivered support and evaluated its effects, results are at risk of bias; acknowledging social desirability bias is good but insufficient. Actionable fix: either commission or report an independent or anonymized third-party validation (external interviews, blinded coder for qualitative data, or independent survey administration). If that is not yet feasible, be explicit in the post about this limitation and avoid broad framing in the title (e.g., change to “Can MEL Help Drive Organizational Change? Lessons and Limitations from Our Work”). Also list concrete next steps you will take to validate claims (anonymous surveys, external evaluator, predefined metrics for 2025).
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback targets core credibility problems: overstated causality, unclear sample/outcome definitions, and evaluator bias from self-evaluation. These are actionable, would materially strengthen the post without a large length penalty (tone changes, a short methods paragraph or appendix, and explicit validation plans), and point out clear 'own-goal' risks the author would be embarrassed about if uncorrected.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I have no record of a notable EA/rationalist figure named Nicoll Peracha (possibly a pseudonym). The name does not appear among well-known EA authors, conference speakers, or major publications in my training data through mid‑2024. Likely a very small or niche online presence; if you have links or context I can reassess.

PostClarity.explanation: Overall clear and well-structured: the post has a concise title, logical headings, concrete examples, and helpful metrics (e.g. number of organisations, tracked changes, satisfaction rating). The main argument — that MEL can drive program changes if accompanied by hands‑on, simplified support and system integration — is easy to follow. Weaknesses: some denominators and sample sizes are scattered (27 organisations worked with, but in‑depth work/survey sizes vary: 9 tracked orgs, 5 interviewed), which could confuse readers about how representative findings are; a few minor repetitions and phrasing choices reduce tightness. Making sample sizes and scope explicit up front and trimming small redundancies would push this toward a 9–10.

PostNovelty.explanation: Most claims are expected to readers familiar with EA and nonprofit evaluation: MEL can change programs with hands-on support, barriers are time/complexity and the need for integration and leadership, and selection bias matters. What is modestly novel is the concrete, small‑scale empirical evidence from 27 animal‑advocacy orgs (specific examples like redesigning a meat‑reduction program or dropping leafleting) and the practical lessons about simplifying tools and implementation support. The mention of exploring AI for streamlining MEL is contemporary but not conceptually new. For a general educated audience these applied findings are slightly more informative than for EA Forum readers, but still not highly original.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post presents a coherent and plausible argument that hands-on MEL support can prompt concrete program and process changes, gives tracked examples, and candidly acknowledges key biases and implementation barriers. The logic about needing integration and ownership for sustainability is sensible. Weaknesses: Evidence is limited and largely observational — small and selected samples (9 organizations for tracked changes, 5 interviewed), no control/comparison group, unclear definitions and methods for tracking changes, short follow-up and no measurement of downstream outcomes (e.g., impact on target behavior or animal welfare), and reliance on potentially biased satisfaction/self-report measures. These issues weaken causal claims and generalizability.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes:
Most of the post’s core empirical claims are verifiable from The Mission Motor’s public materials. Their website’s “Our Results” page explicitly states the headline numbers cited in the post (27 organisations supported between Sep 2023–Dec 2024; 8 long‑term, 19 short‑term; 16 implemented changes tracked across 9 intensively supported organisations and 13 changes in progress) and gives the same illustrative examples and testimonials. A publicly shared change-tracking Google Sheet (view-only) also shows the change counts and breakdowns (total tracked changes, completed vs ongoing) and therefore corroborates the account that MEL support led to multiple tangible program changes. The organisation’s services pages further corroborate claims about webinars, Slack meetups, and the types of MEL deliverables they produce (Theories of Change, monitoring frameworks, data tools). 

Limitations / weaknesses: a few specific numbers in the EA Forum post are not visible in the public pages I could access (notably the “31 MEL deliverables” total, the reported 9/10 average satisfaction score, and the line about “2 of the 29 ongoing or completed changes being made without our prompting”). These may appear in the linked 2023–2024 “years in review” PDF or internal tabs of the Google Drive (the PDF required signing in / the Drive PDF view was not rendered in my browser session), so I could not independently confirm those particular figures from a publicly accessible document. Overall, most major empirical claims are well-supported by the organisation’s public web pages and their shared change-tracking sheet; a few specific metrics appear to come from internal reporting and were not independently accessible in the public files I could open.
